Award.AwardTitle: Automated Intrusive Algorithms for Numerical Simulation of Partial Differential Equations via Software-Based Frechet Differentiation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract: Automated intrusive algorithms for numerical<br/>simulation of partial differential equations via software-based<br/>Frechet differentiation <br/><br/><br/>Computers were invented to automate tedious and error-prone numerical<br/>computations; ironically, programming computers is itself a tedious<br/>and error-prone task. Given the importance and expense of developing<br/>scientific simulation programs, it is worth studying whether computers<br/>can improve the development, as well as the execution, of these<br/>programs. This project focuses on the open-source software Sundance,<br/>which automates transition from high-level mathematical abstractions<br/>to high-performance, parallel partial differential equation (PDE)<br/>simulation code, freeing users from the burden of low-level<br/>programming. This approach can reduce simulator development time from<br/>months or years to days or even hours. Less obvious, but equally<br/>important, benefits of basing software firmly on mathematical<br/>abstractions are that internal performance improvements can be<br/>automated, and that intrusive algorithms -- algorithms that require<br/>transformation of the equation set to produce nonstandard operators --<br/>can be implemented much more easily because such transformations can<br/>be carried out automatically.<br/><br/>This is enabled by formulating programming tasks as mathematical<br/>problems whose solutions are then automated. Central to this is a <br/>theorem establishing Frechet differentiation as a ``bridge'' between<br/>high-level symbolic programming and high-performance numerical<br/>computing. Previous work has laid the foundations for this; this<br/>extends those results work to other aspects of PDE simulation and to<br/>non-PDE paradigms such as density functional theory (DFT), and <br/>investigates intrusive preconditioners for coupled multiphysics<br/>problems. The combination of automatic high performance and<br/>the ready availability of efficient intrusive algorithms for<br/>preconditioning, sensitivity analysis, and PDE-constrained<br/>optimization makes it possible for a high-level, general-purpose tool<br/>such as Sundance to actually outperform hand-coded special-purpose<br/>simulators. The ready availability of advanced optimization<br/>algorithms with finite element discretizations for nonlinear coupled<br/>systems, all with efficient implementation and a short development<br/>cycle, will be transformative to how computational scientists work. <br/><br/><br/>
